intro: Pimpinella sikkimensis, commonly known as the Sikkim cow parsley, is a flowering plant native to the Himalayan regions of India, Nepal, and Bhutan. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from June to August. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in forested areas and along stream banks. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
